brief_summary.textblock:
RATIONALE: Studying samples of tumor tissue from patients with cancer in the laboratory may
      help doctors identify biomarkers related to cancer.

      PURPOSE: This clinical trial studies tumor tissue from patients with rhabdomyosarcoma to
      identify important proteins and biomarkers.

clinical_study.brief_title: Biomarkers in Patients With Advanced Rhabdomyosarcoma

detailed_description.textblock:
OBJECTIVES:

        -  To investigate whether the expression of a subset of proteins (by
           immunohistochemistry), known to be involved in the Pax3, Pax7, and Patched-1
           neuromuscular development pathways, are dysregulated in advanced and relapsed alveolar
           and embryonal rhabdomyosarcomas.

      OUTLINE: Iimmunohistochemistry is performed for each candidate target (Pax3, Pax7, and
      Patched-1) in each disease (alveolar, embryonal, and anaplastic rhabdomyosarcoma) for tissue
      microarray analysis.

criteria.textblock:
DISEASE CHARACTERISTICS:

          -  8 tissue microarrays (TMA) slides of the following diseases available:

               -  Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma

               -  Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma

               -  Anaplastic rhabdomyosarcoma

        PATIENT CHARACTERISTICS:

          -  Not specified

        PRIOR CONCURRENT THERAPY:

          -  Not specified

keyword: stage III adult soft tissue sarcoma
stage IV adult soft tissue sarcoma

link.description: Clinical trial summary from the National Cancer Institute's PDQ® database

clinical_study.official_title: Developmental Pathway Drug-Targets in Advanced Rhabdomyosarcomas

primary_outcome.measure: Prevalence of the candidate target (Pax3, Pax7, or Patched-1), and whether the candidate target is expressed in the tumor vs stroma

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

responsible_party.organization: Children's Oncology Group - Group Chair Office
